comments.content:
Does it come from London Underground signage? You won’t find an exact match, but your best bets are [ITC Johnston](http://web.archive.org/web/20080410040814/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/creative_alliance/itc_johnston_bold/?sample_text=PILLGUN&sample_size=60&acs_p=1&acs_pt=24&acs=1) and [P22 Johnston Underground](http://web.archive.org/web/20080410040814/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/p22/p22_johnston_underground_bold/?sample_text=PILLGUN&sample_size=60&acs_p=1&acs_pt=24&acs=1).

More [alternatives to Gill Sans](http://web.archive.org/web/20080410040814/http:/typographica.org/001084.php).

L’s too narrow for Johnston. Also note that the L’s are not the same width which suggests that this is the work of a wartime lettering artist. It reminds me of a wartime (WW2) poster that was on here a couple of months ago which probably wasn’t exactly identified at the time either. Hmmmm. Not sure really, but definitely ’Ditchling-esque’.

It raises an interesting proposition, that of an LL ligature where the first arm is shorter. Anyone else come across that? Should the arm of an L change its length depending on the next character. Is that even OpenTypossible?
Think it’s a trademark so all the more likely to be custom. Quick internet search reveals nothing to do with WW2 so sorry about that! Can’t find that poster thread so sorry again.
